title: F. D. Roosevelt on freedom - purpose

content.description:
“In the future days, which we seek to make secure, we look forward to a world founded upon four essential human freedoms.

“The first is freedom of speech and expression—everywhere in the world.

“The second is freedom of every person to worship God in his own way—everywhere in the world.

“The third is freedom from want—which, translated into world terms, means economic understandings which will secure to every nation a healthy peacetime life for its inhabitants—everywhere in the world.

“The fourth is freedom from fear—which, translated into world terms, means a world-wide reduction of armaments to such a point and in such a thorough fashion that no nation will be in a position to commit an act of physical aggression against any neighbor—anywhere in the world.”

President Franklin D. Roosevelt, State of the Union address, January 1941
content.question: Roosevelt’s speech was most likely intended to increase public support for

choices.label: extending New Deal programs to guarantee unemployment benefits
integrating the United States armed forces
aiding the Allies in Europe during the Second World War
enhancing rights protected by the United States Constitution

content.answer: aiding the Allies in Europe during the Second World War
